app.title: My Watershed - Central Puget Sound
app.name: My Watershed
app.meta_description: Welcome! We are here to educate and inspire action for our Central Puget Sound watersheds.

layerGroups.popupContent:
Land use type:

{{CONSOL20}}

body: The topography basemap layer shows the terrain and features of the land through hill shading and natural vegetation colors. The word topography comes from the greek word tópos meaning ‘place’ and latin root graphy meaning ‘study of’, so it literally means the study of place. This map layer also shows roads and labels for various features. Try zooming in and out with just this layer to see how the labeling changes! Find a hill, a forest, or a river near where you live!

The hillshade basemap layer portrays the shape of the land using a grayscale 3D representation of the surface, with the sun's relative position taken into account for shading the image. Hillshading is a technique for creating relief maps, showing the topographical shape of hills and mountains using shading (levels of gray) on a map, just to indicate relative slopes, mountain ridges, not absolute height. Try comparing this to contour lines!

The hydrography base map layer shows the shapes of shorelines of rivers, lakes, and oceans. "Hydro" is a Greek root meaning "water," which explains why hydrography is the science and study of surveying and charting bodies of water. Compare this to the Bathymetry layer!

Bathymetry studies the land shapes, depths, and slopes of bodies of water. It is like an underwater hillshade layer! Land features include administrative boundaries, cities, inland waters, roads overlaid on land cover, and shaded relief imagery. This layer might catch the eye of anyone interested in ocean data, including marine GIS professionals.

The satellite view shows overhead imagery of an area. Satellites are artificial bodies placed in orbit around the earth to collect information, in this case, images of the land. Airplanes and drones may take closer photos. See how the quality changes at different zoom levels!

This map layer was built from individual photos taken from a slow-moving airplane in 1936. They used a big camera and generated a 3-foot by 3-foot footprint. They only took pictures of the more populated areas of King County that were of interest at the time. The prints were mounted on a hardboard and stored away. Then, each hardboard print was scanned and blended to make the digital layer. The original 0.5-foot pixel resolution was resampled to a 1-foot pixel. The purpose of the imagery is to provide historical comparison and accurately identify and archive related historical documents. 1936 was likely the time of your great-grandparents. Focus on a neighborhood, crossroads, or commercial crossroads. Ask yourself: if you were a kid in 1936, what would you know? What would your day be like? How much did a loaf of bread cost or a dinner out with your family? Did your family have a car? A phone? A radio? Did most houses have a vegetable garden?

This map layer details 1998 panchromatic black-and-white aerial imagery from airplanes featuring King County and southwestern Snohomish County. The Washington State Department of Natural Resources acquired the imagery at a resolution of 3 feet per pixel under leaf-on conditions.
The simple canvas base layer shows roads, parks, and bodies of water but all in greyscale. It helps provide context as you explore other layers without being distracting.
The projects layer highlights projects in the King County area advancing the community towards a more just and sustainable world.

modal.body: WRIA stands for Water Resource Inventory Area. Each WRIA is a geographic area used by the Department of Ecology to manage, regulate, and protect the watersheds of our state. Each WRIA is very similar to a watershed which is defined by higher elevations that capture precipitation and funnel rain and snowmelt through smaller sub basins into streams, tributaries, and rivers. One of the big advantages of WRIAs is to engage multiple jurisdictions in shared decision making around salmon recovery, forests, floodplains, and farms.

body: Sub-basins are smaller regions within watersheds. All water within a sub-basin flows to a mutual outlet, like a river or lake. Within sub-basins, we find even smaller areas called catchments. See if you can find the sub-basin and catchment that your home or school is near. Can you picture the boundaries of the catchment? Do they correspond to geographic features like ridges or hills? Try switching on the topography base map too! Do you see any relationship between topography and catchments?

This layer reveals the approximate sites where traditional Salish villages of the Puget Sound region were. It is fascinating to analyze the many clusters along rivers and lakes. If we assume one village may be inhabited by several hundred people, how could there be this many villages so close together? Were salmon so incredibly abundant that all of these people could thrive? The information for this map layer was geolocated by students, site by site, from an original digital map created by Tom Dailey sometime before 2010. A record of the original map is in a blog called Northwest Coast Archaeology. Although there hasn't been much activity over the last decade, the map lives on.

In the early 1900s, the area near the river's mouth was dredged and straightened out to benefit industrial development. Click on this layer to see the original path of the river and how much it has changed.

Contour Lines are lines of constant elevation (aka isolines), which means every point in one of the lines is the same height above sea level. These lines help show the topography or shape of the land, notice an area where the lines get really close together, this means an area of rapid height change i.e. a steep slope. Zoom in to see elevation labels and notice how the scale changes at different zoom levels!

Impervious surfaces are areas that don’t allow water to pass through. For example, buildings and concrete pavement (exceptions apply) are impervious surfaces and change how water moves, flows, and picks up pollutants. Which areas are the darkest, meaning they have the most impervious surfaces? Data for this map layer is sourced from King County and covers most of Central Puget Sound.

This layer categorizes sections along the riverbanks as low, medium, high, or critical. The amount of solar radiation hitting an area will determine stream temperature. "Riparian" refers to the banks and adjacent wetlands of rivers, while "solar" refers to how much sunlight is reaching an area.

The wastewater system layer shows sewer lines that transport wastewater from your home, school, or business that the city maintains through larger pipes to the treatment centers that King County maintains.

A farmers market is a place for local farmers to sell fresh produce and dairy, meat, and bakery products directly to buyers, usually in an outdoor booth setting. Who has the most access to fresh, organic, local, and sustainable food? Is there a farmers market near you?
Salmon complete their life cycle by spawning in the same freshwater streams in which they were born. It is crucial to protect these areas to keep salmon, a keystone species, healthy.

modal.body: WRIA 7 is the Snohomish Watershed and includes three major rivers. It provides municipal water for Everett, Bellevue, Seattle, and more. WRIA stands for Water Resource Inventory Area. Each WRIA is a geographic area used by the Department of Ecology to manage, regulate, and protect the watersheds of our state. Each WRIA is very similar to a watershed which is defined by higher elevations that capture precipitation and funnel rain and snowmelt through smaller sub basins into streams, tributaries, and rivers. One of the big advantages of WRIAs is to engage multiple jurisdictions in shared decision making around salmon recovery, forests, floodplains, and farms.

WRIA 8 is the Cedar and Sammamish Basin and contains two major rivers and three major lakes which include Lake Union and Lake Washington. WRIA stands for Water Resource Inventory Area. Each WRIA is a geographic area used by the Department of Ecology to manage, regulate, and protect the watersheds of our state. Each WRIA is very similar to a watershed which is defined by higher elevations that capture precipitation and funnel rain and snowmelt through smaller sub basins into streams, tributaries, and rivers. One of the big advantages of WRIAs is to engage multiple jurisdictions in shared decision making around salmon recovery, forests, floodplains, and farms.

WRIA 9 is the Green/ Duwamish River Watershed. WRIA stands for Water Resource Inventory Area. Each WRIA is a geographic area used by the Department of Ecology to manage, regulate, and protect the watersheds of our state. Each WRIA is very similar to a watershed which is defined by higher elevations that capture precipitation and funnel rain and snowmelt through smaller sub basins into streams, tributaries, and rivers. One of the big advantages of WRIAs is to engage multiple jurisdictions in shared decision making around salmon recovery, forests, floodplains, and farms.

WRIA 10 is the White-Puyallap river basin. WRIA stands for Water Resource Inventory Area. Each WRIA is a geographic area used by the Department of Ecology to manage, regulate, and protect the watersheds of our state. Each WRIA is very similar to a watershed which is defined by higher elevations that capture precipitation and funnel rain and snowmelt through smaller sub basins into streams, tributaries, and rivers. One of the big advantages of WRIAs is to engage multiple jurisdictions in shared decision making around salmon recovery, forests, floodplains, and farms.

WRIA 11 is the Nisqually Watershed. WRIA stands for Water Resource Inventory Area. Each WRIA is a geographic area used by the Department of Ecology to manage, regulate, and protect the watersheds of our state. Each WRIA is very similar to a watershed which is defined by higher elevations that capture precipitation and funnel rain and snowmelt through smaller sub basins into streams, tributaries, and rivers. One of the big advantages of WRIAs is to engage multiple jurisdictions in shared decision making around salmon recovery, forests, floodplains, and farms.

WRIA 12 is the Chambers-Clover watershed. WRIA stands for Water Resource Inventory Area. Each WRIA is a geographic area used by the Department of Ecology to manage, regulate, and protect the watersheds of our state. Each WRIA is very similar to a watershed which is defined by higher elevations that capture precipitation and funnel rain and snowmelt through smaller sub basins into streams, tributaries, and rivers. One of the big advantages of WRIAs is to engage multiple jurisdictions in shared decision making around salmon recovery, forests, floodplains, and farms.

body: Land use revolves around the construction of settlements and semi-natural habitats through the modification of the natural environment. The land is often divided into sections corresponding with its use; some categories include rural area, forest, industrial/manufacturing, single/multi-residential, park/golf course/trail/open space, central business district, and agriculture-related.

A boundary is a real or imaginary line that separates two things. In geography, boundaries separate different regions of Earth. City boundaries are imaginary lines used to indicate the boundary of cities.

School Districts are separated by imaginary lines to indicate single-purpose governmental units that operate local public primary and secondary schools. Notice the size of some districts compared to others, are there significant differences to report?

The Schools and Colleges map layer informs you of the location of many educational institutions in an area. Do you see schooling focused in a central location? Compare this layer with the School Districts map layer. What do you observe?

A Tree Equity Score indicates whether a neighborhood has enough trees to address environmental inequities like air pollution. A color correspondent indicates multiple scores, 100 represents tree equity has been reached, and 0 means tree equity has not been reached. Compare this layer to the City Boundaries map layer. Do you see tree equity differentiating between locations?

This map layer portrays the percentage of neighborhoods below the Double Poverty Level in King County. The poverty line is the minimum amount of income thought to live off of in a country. A color correspondent indicates the percentage of the population below the line, a percentage of 50%+ means that more than half of the population is in poverty. Compare this layer to the Life Expectancy map layer. What conclusions can you draw between poverty and life expectancy?

This map layer portrays the percentage of people of color residing within neighborhoods in King County. A color correspondent indicates the percentage of POC residents, 50%+ means that more than half of the neighborhood residents are people of color.

This map layer portrays the percentage of foreign-born residents within neighborhoods in King County. A color correspondent indicates the percentage of foreign-born residents, 40%+ means that more than forty percent of the residents were born in a foreign nation.

This map layer portrays the life expectancy of residents within neighborhoods in King County. A color correspondent indicates the average lifetime in years of residents, and the lightest shade predicts less than 70 years, while the darkest predicts residents living more than 90 years. Compare this layer to the Tree Equity map layer. How important is a tree equity score to a neighborhood’s life expectancy?

fields.name: cover-image
fields.prompt: Insert a compelling cover image and/or project site map
fields.label: Cover image

fields.name: problem-statement
fields.placeholder: What problem are you trying to solve?

fields.name: goal
fields.placeholder: Make it clear, specific, and concise. Best to include your intended impact in the goal statement.

fields.name: location-description
fields.placeholder: Name the street or nearest intersection. Or, if your project is in a natural setting without a clear street address to reference, describe the parcel, park, stream or river mile. For example: “Jasper Park off Riverview Road at river mile 17.” You can also embed images or detailed site maps in this section.

fields.name: background
fields.placeholder: What's the situation? What are the challenges and opportunities?

fields.name: city-goal-alignment
fields.placeholder: Provide annotated links to policies, plans or performance measures of your city or county government. Research your city’s “Climate Action Plan” or “Master Sustainability Plan” or “Environmental Stewardship Plan.” How does your project advance specific actions called out in one of these plans?

fields.name: stakeholders
fields.placeholder: Who cares about this issue? Who needs to care? Be specific. Make a list and describe each stakeholder’s point of view.

fields.name: action-steps
fields.placeholder: List what steps were taken to implement your solution. It’s great to embed images or video showing before and after, or in other ways documenting the “journey” of actions taken.

fields.name: impact-data
fields.placeholder: Provide evidence, data, and a brief narrative explanation. We encourage you to embed a table or graph in this section. If applicable, describe the number and demographics of people directly impacted. Be sure to describe how your project directly supports one or more city goals (local policies, plans or performance measures). Feel free to insert a link to “Read more about this project” or  “See the Full Report.” You might also link to an extensive photo gallery of your project. Pictures are great!

fields.name: next-steps
fields.placeholder: What needs to happen next? What are your plans or recommendations?

attrs.value: Receive email updates on your report

content: Find out more about the various connections in the WRIA 9 Watershed in this informative video journey told through the eyes of a high school senior.
Consider the factors that influence life expectancy, from poverty to environmental health, through this exploration on disparities across King County.
Find out how demographic factors such as life expectancy influence equitable development in Bellevue and Kent in this educational video!
Learn about the modern day effects of Redlining in King County in this informative video journey using maps.
Learn about the phenomenon of Greenlining which is slowly reversing the effects of Redlining in King County in this informative video journey using maps.

This map compares communities across Washington state for their environmental health disparities by showing pollution measures such as diesel emissions, ozone, and hazardous waste sites. Measures like poverty and cardiovascular disease can be found as well. In addition, new insights regarding public investments to buffer environmental health impacts on Washington's communities will be displayed.
Native Land Maps: Territories, Languages, Treaties

This resource maps Indigenous land territories to challenge the way people view their land. The map does not intend to represent legal boundaries of any Indigenous nations but strengthen the spiritual bonds that people have with their land, language, and treaties. Additional features include a teachers' guide and territory acknowledgement.

For most of its history, Seattle was a tightly segregated city, committed to white supremacy and the separation of those considered not white. The maps provided by the University of Washington show the neighborhood distribution of African American, Asian American, Native American, Latino, and White populations across nine decades. This resource also includes the location and history of racially restrictive covenants in Seattle and along the Eastside.
Washington State Treaty Ceded Areas Map

This map portrays the tribal reservations and drafted treaty ceded areas of the Indigenous peoples of Washington State. Ceded areas are off-reservation lands ceded by a tribe to the United States in exchange for protection, services, and possibly cash payments.
Federally Recognized Tribes of Washington State Map
This map displays the present-day reservations of Indigenous people recognized by the United States federal government.
Map for Tracking Toxins in Your Neighborhood

This map displays cleanup sites of the Toxics Cleanup Program within a desired range of a zip code or address in Washington State. The Toxics Cleanup Program (TCP) works to clean up contaminated properties throughout Washington State.
• YouTube - Student Examples of Neighborhood Investigations

This map displays the 62 WRIAs (Water Resource Inventory Area) in Washington State. Type in your address or town name to find yours! Knowing your WRIA can help you find information about water availability, regulations, and more.

This map allows users to find self-guided sites and virtual opportunities to observe salmon migrating to spawn at sites near King County. The TAKE ACTION button educates users on how they can help protect salmon.

This collection of maps shows the distribution of key demographics within King County: income, race/ethnicity, and languages spoken in King County. The resource creates many interesting points of inquiry surrounding the income and racial dynamics in King County.
The United States Census Bureau provides a collection of large-scale maps based on census data surrounding educational attainment, median household income, employment status, and more.
Mapping Inequality - Redlining in New Deal America

This collection of maps includes the color-coded mortgage security grades assigned to neighborhoods in Seattle and Tacoma. Between 1935 and 1940, agents of the federal government's Home Owners' Loan Corporation assigned grades to neighborhoods that reflected their supposed mortgage security. A grade of "A" was deemed minimally risky for banks whereas "D" indicated that the area was hazardous for investors. The HOLC consistently assigned lower grades to neighborhoods consisting of minorities and working class white people which led lenders to refuse to make loans in these areas.

The Food Access Research Atlas presents a spatial overview of food access indicators for low-income and other census tracts using different measures of supermarket accessibility. This map can be downloaded for community planning or research purposes.
This map displays the number and location of Built Green certified properties in the Greater Seattle Area.

This dynamic, multi-layered map features information on salmonid fish distribution, ESA status, juvenile fish monitoring, hatcheries and rearing facilities, and stream blockages. The various map views display data by watershed, county boundary, cities, and at a specified longitude and latitude. The tool also allows students to visually grasp the relationships among habitat features, human development and fish stock status within a watershed or geographic area.

The Waterlines Project Map is a rendering of the Seattle region in the mid-19th century, just prior to non-Indigenous settlement, created using photorealistic aerial views collaged with hand painting. The map content integrates research from the sciences, natural and cultural histories, and informed imaginings. The resource also features four tours of the area’s history presented through the lens of its changing landscape going back 20,000 years.
WRIA 9 - POSTER: Making Our Watershed Fit for a King

This is a great infographic in the form of a larger poster full of rich detail. It’s a high resolution image so you can zoom in to learn about the history, challenges, and opportunities of the Green Duwamish Watershed, from the headwaters all the way downstream to the estuary. Download the Poster. Also, most of the diagrams and infographics combined in this one beautiful poster also serve as the illustrations for the Green Duwamish Watershed Salmon Habitat Plan.
• Executive Summary of the Green Duwamish Salmon Habitat Plan

This collection of map brochures of King County Parks’ system offers trails with year-round accessibility for hiking, mountain biking, and horseback riding. Each of the map brochures focus on a different backcountry location and its trail features and are available to download and print.

This mapping tool helps users map their next bike ride or commute route. The site includes a list of state and local bike and trails maps for Washington State. Check out additional bike maps of the Puget Sound Region below!
• Cascade Bicycle Club - Bike maps in the Puget Sound region
• City of Seattle - Bike map of Seattle

The Sound Impacts online portal maps the location of green infrastructure in Western Washington including rain gardens, permeable pavement, tree planting, green roofs, and more. Additional resources of green infrastructure projects that have been built in Seattle over the past two decades can be found in the resources below!
• Green Stormwater Infrastructure Projects Near You - Seattle
Combined Sewer Outfall Real Time Status Map

This map displays potential combined sewer overflow, or CSO, locations in the Seattle area. Users can view this map before going swimming, wading, fishing, or boating near a CSO warning sign within the City of Seattle. Click on each green dot or CSO outfall symbol to learn more.

The Walk Score interactive map ranks homes and apartments in over 2,800 cities and 10,000 neighborhoods based on their walkability. Users can click on various properties throughout the United States and Canada and view their walkability scores.
This map displays the storm drainage systems located in Kent, Washington including storm sewer lines, detention facilities, pump stations, and drainage utility basin boundaries.

This is a series of seven maps that cover the full length of the Green-Duwamish River, section by section. You can zoom in to see exactly where trees need to be planted to benefit salmon along every river mile. The maps in this series display the priority areas for tree planting due to the lack of tall native trees especially along the Green River and Soos and Newaukum Creeks. The lack of trees causes unhealthy and sometimes lethal conditions for Chinook and other salmon. This map represents one of the Re-Green the Green Revegetation strategies developed by the WRIA 9 Riparian Revegetation Work Group.
• Learn more about the initiative to Re-Green the Green

This map depicts the known freshwater distribution of chinook salmon for Water Resource Inventory Area (WRIA) 8 ore the Cedar, Lake Washington, Lake Sammamish Watershed. The depicted limits of known freshwater distribution of chinook salmon are based upon the collective personal knowledge of participants in the WRIA 8 mapping project and data they gathered from published and unpublished databases. This map may underestimate or overestimate the actual distribution of chinook salmon.
• Learn more about Chinook Salmon Conservation Plan for WRIA 8
Interactive Maps for City of Seattle
The Seattle Department of Transportation hosts more than a dozen very specific interactive map stories, from School Walking and Biking, to Parking Zones, from Urban Forestry to potholes.
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics salmon watersystems pollution foodsystems greenbuilding transportationsystems'>

The City of Bellevue offers a variety of standard PDF maps, downloadable spatial data and interactive web maps that help keep residents and visitors informed. Visit the full Map Gallery or preview featured interactive web maps below to explore city projects, plans and other city initiatives.

OldMapsOnline, a search engine for historical maps, developed out of a love of history and heritage of old maps. The website has been created by Klokan Technologies GmbH, specialists in online map publishing and in applications of open-source software. It aims to demonstrate a combination of tools for publishing historical maps with a focus on their easy accessibility for the general public. ince January, 2013, the project has been improved and maintained by volunteers and the team of Klokan Technologies GmbH in their free time. Find dozens of old Seattle Maps including some really early ones from 1897.

This is a high resolution poster of an historical drawing depicting what Seattle looked like in 1891. It is drawn from an oblique, bird’s eye view. By clicking on the poster, you can scroll around and zoom in for a fascinating tour of Seattle and the surrounding parts of King County in 1891.
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics indigenous history salmon watersystems pollution transportationsystems'>

This beautiful map from 1909 shows downtown Seattle and a few of the surrounding small communities that will later become incorporated as Seattle neighborhoods. It also features the natural estuary and broad meandering floodplain of the Duwamish Valley. This image was rendered just a few years before the construction of Harbor Island and the channelization of the Duwamish River. This choice will rapidly advance Seattle’s deep port Industrial development, but will destroy thousands of acres of vital Salmon habitat.
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics indigenous history salmon watersystems pollution transportationsystems'>

This beautiful map from 1897 shows much of King and Snohomish County including east of Lake Sammamish. You can scroll around and zoom in on this drawing to see the street grid of old Seattle, the natural estuary and broad meandering floodplain of the Duwamish Valley and the largely undeveloped land of all the suburban communities we know today. This was only about 130 years ago. The pace of urban development in our region is pretty breathtaking and has come with both intended and unintended consequences.
People Commuting To Work By Biking in King County

Another fascinating map story from King County’s Communities Count, a dashboard with geospatial data on many different attributes and behaviors in our communities. This map, on adults who commute to work by biking, includes trends on age, race, poverty, and neighborhoods.
People Commuting To Work By Walking in King County

Another fascinating map story from King County’s Communities Count, a dashboard with geospatial data on many different attributes and behaviors in our communities. This map, on adults who commute to work by walking, includes trends on age, race, poverty, and neighborhoods.

This is not exactly a map, but we couldn't leave it out, as it is the earliest known drawing of downtown Seattle, which was little more than an outpost that included a fort, a sawmill, a church, and a house of prostituion. See if you can figure out from this drawing and other historical maps of old Seattle where the stadiums, ferry terminals, and skyscrapers would be today. Notice that right behind this cluster of little buildings looms the massive old growth forest that once blanketed every acre of land all the way up to the Cascades. A Lieutenant in the US Navy sketched this view while at anchor in Elliot Bay during the Treaty Wars of 1855-56. Why were their treaty wars?
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics indigenous history salmon watersystems pollution foodsystems greenbuilding transportationsystems'>

This is a series of seven drawings of a fictitious watershed showing the evolution of human development decisions based on the original natural resources of the watershed. The series takes us from the watershed in its natural state before human settlement, to the first native village of five longhouses near the estuary, all the way to complete urbanization, much like the development story of Seattle and King County and the local watershed that accommodated such rapid growth. The series was hand drawn by Peter Donaldson, Director of Learning for Sustainability Ambassadors. The process began with an initial watershed map, then the addition of five longhouses and a few trails for hunting and gathering, then the addition of a trading fort and sawmill, and so on. Each subsequent layer was photocopied before more detail was added. There is no legend, timeframe, or explanation of the iconography. It is a puzzle with many possible explanations for the intended and unintended consequences of human impact on the environment. Try making one of your own.

This useful collection of maps at the County level includes natural resource topics such as: average annual precipitation, 100-year and 500-year floodplains, land use, water quality in small lakes, and noxious weed distribution.
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics history salmon watersystems pollution foodsystems greenbuilding transportationsystems'>
Historical Aerial Photos of Communities in King County

The image in the thumbnail is downtown Redmond in 1936. This fascinating collection includes only a few selected King County Communities, but it gives you an awesome window into the rapid development of our landscape. Check out some of the other cities.
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics equity pollution foodsystems transportationsystems'>
What makes Georgetown and South Park Healthy and Unhealthy Maps

The Duwamish River Cleanup Coalition/Technical Advisory Group used Community Based Participatory Research in Georgetown and South Park to retrieve information about how to improve community health and eliminate health disparities. The maps communicate all health related concerns as well as features that contribute to a healthy community.
San Francisco Map of Tap Water Stations

San Francisco Public Utilities Commision has installed lead-free outdoor water bottle refilling stations ("tap stations") around the City to provide everyone with free access to high-quality tap water while on the go. This encourages conservation of natural resources and reduces waste from single-use plastic water bottles. Why can’t we have a map like this in our own community?

This map highlights Tree Equity Scores for a select number of cities in each Tree Equity Score Pilot location. Once you have clicked on the map you can explore the data that goes into calculating each Tree Equity Score. We have also posted this as an interactive map layer on the main map.
Washington Snowpack Summary Maps and Graphs
It's amazing! The data on these maps is updated daily. You will find maps on snow water equivalent, snow density, snow depth, precipitation, and more.
Climate Change GIS Open Data Portal

King County has created a beta-version Climate GIS Open Data portal for GIS professionals to support the use of spatial analysis in preparing for and adapting to the impacts of climate change. Users can use the site to view or download GIS data for the Puget Sound basin. Categories include: Temperature, Precipitation, Snowpack, Streamflow, Sea Level. Data for this platform were provided by the University of Washington Climate Impacts Group and are based on analyses conducted for the 2015 Puget Sound State of Knowledge report.

What is your stream subbasin? Do storm drains on your street carry pollution to Puget Sound? What’s the equity tree score in your neighborhood? Why is there a geographic correlation between poverty, people of color, and life expectancy?
Switch Base Maps and mix and match Map Layers to discover the story of your place.
Click SWIPE to slide back and forth between any two layers to see what new stories are revealed to you.

Love maps? Click on LOVE to find a whole other world of maps we love. Be curious. Expand your geographic literacy. When you think about it, what human story is not anchored to the landscape in some way?
Teachers will find LESSONS that help design map reading into lots of different academic subjects

Click on any of the “little green dots” to be inspired by youth-led Impact Projects, curriculum-driven Classroom Projects, and Community Case Studies led by our nonprofit partners or by local governments like your city and county.

Click on the STORIES tab to see inspired student examples of getting lost and found in a map journey through a series of self-imposed questions. Curiosity is a sign of intelligence! Write your own map story.

Since time immemorial the native people of this land have known every stream, meadow and floodplain. (Click on the native village sites). They took good care of the land and water and the natural resources they depended on. The rivers were the freeways for commercial and cultural exchange. They formed the fundamental map stories of the community. They still do. We just take all of this for granted.
Meanwhile, Salmon are coming home to spawn each year expecting home to be there when they arrive.

Mywater.world is powered by Mapseed, an open source map-based data collection tool. Mapseed powers community engagement through beautiful visuals and powerful data aggregation tools. Since all of these maps are sourced openly from other places, not all of them have the same geographic reach. Some Base Maps cover the whole continent while some map layers cover only King County. Read more about Mapseed here!
Thank you to our Funders and Sponsors

Thank you Cascade Water Alliance for supporting student and teacher research on SNOTEL data analysis as a foundational understanding for water resource management decision making. And for supporting the original design of the PBL Curriculum Design Lab and Teacher Fellows Program.
Thank you King County WaterWorks Grant Program for supporting partnership building, curriculum design, and student impact projects related to water quality.
A big thank you to The Russell Family Foundation for your support of our growth and stability as a learning organization. You are a creative and insightful partner in philanthropy.

The Community impact mapping website is a product of Sustainability Ambassadors. We are a professional development program for student leaders, teacher leaders, and community leaders committed to rapidly advance a sustainable future by aligning classroom rigor with community relevance for real world impact.

We support a year-round training program for highly motivated youth, a paid Equity Advocacy Internship, a Green Jobs Youth Pathways Portal, and a Teacher Fellows Program, working with hundreds of educators to design new models of problem-based, place-based learning around a shared vision of educating for sustainability.

We focus on middle school and high school youth, the teachers and school districts that guide their learning, and the community stakeholders, local government and business leaders who are relying on the next generation to be engaged voters, informed taxpayers, conscious consumers, and employees who can create and lead sustainability initiatives.
Get the latest resources and impact stories: SIGN UP
DONATE today to help us build this map tool and reach more students and teachers.
